高等数学在工程，物理，以及社会科学中起着重要作用，是大学教育的重要组成部分。本课程，"高等数学基础"，涵盖了高等数学的核心思想，涉及极限、微分学、积分学和无穷级数等，并结合了相关应用。本课程适用于第一次接触高等数学的学生，可作为工程、物理以及社会科学等专业学生的基础数学课。

人工智能是研究机器模拟人类智能、智能行为及其规律的一门学科，机器学习是人工智能的核心和基础，研究如何使用机器来模拟人类学习活动，是使计算机具有人类智能的根本途径。本课程讲授与机器学习相关的重要主题：机器学习系统基本要素和结构，经典的和现代的机器学习方法，以及与文本、语音、图像识别和机器翻译等有关的机器学习方法应用。课程重点在建立机器学习系统的基本理论和技术，进而能够设计和实现某些近似于人类学习行为的计算系统。课程关注机器学习领域最新的研究趋势和应用。完成本课程后，学生将对人工智能的机器学习领域有一个全面的了解，有能力开始研究与模拟人类学习行为相关的计算技术，能够针对智能计算的应用需求，分析、选择、架构、设计和实现某些近似于人类智能行为的计算系统。x

Practical side. During the course, students will work in small groups to implement a some compiler components: lexer, parser, and a simple interpreter. The source language is a fragment of C++ (but no previous knowledge of C++ is presupposed). The interpreter reads the source code and executes the program. These components will be reused in Part 2 of the course to build a complete compiler to JVM (Java Virtual Machine). But the course is also doable without continuing to Part 2. Theoretical side. The students will learn about the formal structures and algorithms that enable compiler construction in an efficient and principled way: grammars, parsers, syntax-directed translation, and operational semantics. My plan is that these concepts are first explained in lectures, after which they are immediately put into practice in supervised coding sessions. The use of tools (lexer and parser generation, boilerplate code generation) will make the course doable in 16 hours total. As a programming language, Java would be the easiest choice, but I could also support Haskell, C++, and perhaps C#.

Practical side. Building on Part 1, students will work in small groups to implement a the rest of a complete compiler: type checker and code generator. The source language is a fragment of C++ and the target language is Java Virtual Machine (JVM). The compiler will convert source programs to JVM code executable in a Java interpreter. Theoretical side. The students will learn about type checking, machine languages and code generation, and how to implement the corresponding compiler components. As a programming language, Java would be the easiest choice, but I could also support Haskell, C++, and perhaps C#.

This course will cover the current best-in-practice LEAN methodologies of how to build a product from a management standpoint. Example lectures will include: “Managing Scope”, “MVP Development and Sprint Planning”, and “Leading an Agile brainstorming session”. Students will come away from this course with an improved ability to approach problems with a technical mindset and break them down into manageable chunks. Students can apply learnings from this course into starting their own company, building a product within a team, or acting as a technical consultant.

The purpose of this course is to demonstrate silicon valley standards for development environments, from the perspective of a software engineer. Example lectures will include “Using Git cleanly”, “Bug reporting, reproduction, and testing”, “Code Refactoring”, and “Reducing technical debt”. Students will come away from this course with knowledge of some of the popular tools and processes being used in modern startups. They will also have a better grasp of the concepts to look for in choosing their own particular set of tools and processes.

The most commonly used programming languages today are imperative. University computer science courses are almost exclusively taught using imperative languages, and commercial
application development relies heavily on imperative languages such as Java, C, C++ and many new languages, tailored for particular kinds of application development. When digital computers were introduced in the mid 1940s, programs consisted of sequences of instructions in machine language, describing step-by-step, how to compute a result. Today’s programming languages evolved from machine language, and have the same fundamental structure: that is, programs are step-by-step descriptions of how to compute results.
In contrast, declarative languages are based on a different approach to computation: a declarative program specifies what is to be computed, not how to compute it. Such languages
are best suited to symbolic rather than numerical problem solving, and require a different way of thinking about computing problems. Declarative programming is extremely useful for rapid prototyping, and in various forms, is used for specific tasks in industry.
This course presents a brief history and survey of declarative languages, but focusses primarily on two declarative models: functional programming and logic programming.

"Content:
The short course is designed for general researchers (academicians, graduate students, practicians in the field, etc.) working and/or planning to work in data mining.
The course will introduce the theoretical background of various techniques developed in the context of data mining such as clustering, classification, regression and association mining. The course will focus mostly on the algorithms and their strengths and weaknesses.
The participants will also have the opportunity for on-hands application of the techniques with WEKA during the course. Course Outline:
1. Introduction to Data Mining Process

？ Costs in data mining
4. Supervised Learning
？ Classification
o Decision Trees
o Naive Bayes
o Logistic Regression
o Instance Based Learning
？ Regression
5. Feature Selection and Weighting
？ Feature Selection
？ Feature Weighting
？ Feature Extraction (PCA)
6. Association Rule Mining"

This course includes three parts: The first part is the fundamentals of programming, the main contents. This section is mainly used to review the knowledge which students have studied in the C language course and at the same time to study grammar expansion knowledge of the c + + language . The second part is the object-oriented programming; this section is the core part of this course. The third part is the data structures, advanced features of C++ and object-oriented program design. The main aim about this section is to strengthen students the further understanding of C++ language and object-oriented programming method. After studying this course, students should have a comprehensive understanding of the c++ language and object-oriented program design method, and have the ability to develop a simple application program by C++ and object-oriented method.

This course introduces students to concepts, methods and tools in analysis of software requirement, including domain engineering, techniques for discovering and eliciting requirements, languages and models for representing requirements. It also introduces  analysis and validation techniques, including need, goal, and use case analysis; requirements in the context of system engineering; specifying and measuring external qualities: performance, reliability, availability, safety, security, etc.; specifying and analyzing requirements for various types of systems: embedded systems, consumer systems, web-based systems, business systems, systems for scientists and other engineers, resolving feature interactions; requirements documentation standards; traceability; human factors; requirements in the context of agile processes; requirements management: Handling requirements changes.

本课程的意义有两个方面：其一、从IT的历史和发展角度：计算机以及应用到了各个学科和领域，但是不同专业的学生，对计算机的应用背景、能力和局限存在一定误解，甚至有一层神秘面纱。而了解一个事务的现在和未来的最好方式之一就是了解其发展历史。其二、从大学生双创的角度：有了以上IT的历史和发展观，就可以更好的把握历史脉搏，规律性的总结和预测IT的未来发展趋势和走向，从而更好的进行大学生双创。
本课程的意义在意通过普及计算机发展历史中的群星闪耀的事件、人物、组织和团体，让学生对计算机对其学科的影响和意义，有深入了理解。并且能够提高其计算机应用的能力，从而提高其综合素质。同时，结合当前的“大众创新，万众创业”，可以有效的指导大学生的双创项目和比赛。（1）IT历史和发展：旨在让学生了解计算机发展史上的波澜起伏和壮丽奇幻，从而增加对计算机科学、技术乃至整个IT学科的兴趣。讲述计算机发展历史，重点包括一些重点的历史事件、对发展做出卓越贡献的人、公司和组织机构，并试图揭示计算机发展的趋势和未来方向，以及对人类生存和发展的影响。（2）大学生双创：旨在有效的指导同学的大学生双创活动，包括大创项目和比赛（如互联网+、挑战杯等），充分利用校级公选课的优势，促进交叉学科的融合，鼓励不同专业的同学组队进行创意构思和创意设计，最终促进川大的大学生双创活动

The Role of Visual Representation in Software Development
The Role of Visual Representation in Software Development

The introduction of graphics-based operating systems in the mid-80s instigated a majorrevolution in the way users interact with computers, introducing or popularising notions suchas “point-and-click”, “drag-and-drop”, “WYSIWYG”, “GUI” and so forth. As a result,computers quickly became accessible to a much wider group of users. For example, these dayspersonal computers are almost universally used by arts students to write, format and printpapers. This would have been unthinkable 30 years ago.The immediate beneficiaries of this revolution were individuals we now call “end-users”.Software developers, on the other hand, faced a great increase in the complexity of their task,which now was no longer just writing programs to compute results from data, but includedvery complex programs to manage graphical user interfaces.This course looks at the history and evolution of software visualiation, and examines ways inwhich software structures and processes such as algorithms, data and application models canbe represented. In particular, we focus on the use of visual representations of algorithms, or“visual programming languages”, and consider questions concerning the suitability of visuallanguages to the tasks they are designed for, the advantages and disadvantages of visualprogramming compared with textual programming. We will also investigate some visualprogramming models, and may look at visual representation of concepts not directly relatedto software construction.There is no textbook for this course. The primary source materials will be class notes andselected papers from the literature.While there are no formal prerequisites, it would be helpful for students to have anunderstanding of some non-standard programming languages, such as Lisp or its derivatives,or Prolog.
Industrial Innovation based on Smart Objects 1
Industrial Innovation based on Smart Objects 1

This course isimplemented as a projectwhere the participants design and implement an innovative smart objectproduct and make a plan on whatisrequired for commercial utilization of the smart objectproduct. The projectintroduces the necessarytechnology, implementationtools, prototyping techniques, design and creativityapproaches and commercializationapproaches. Based on the technicalknowledge, the students design the concept of the innovativeproduct and implementit at least partly. Hardware prototypingisbased on using hardware such as the Arduinomicrocontrollerusing the Arduinoprogramminglanguage and the Raspberry PI mini computer using the Python programminglanguage. The studentsalsocreate document thatoutlines how the resulting smart objectproductcouldbecommercialized.This course is the second part of my proposed teaching.
